bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, February 25, 1918

div1.p: Kean informs Gorgas of his transfer to post of Deputy Chief Surgeon of American Expeditionary Forces. He also describes command reorganizations and the status of ambulance service.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, February 25, 1918
div1.opener:
Kean to Gorgas-
JRK-OFH
AMERICAN EXPEDITIONARY FORCES
Headquarters, Service of the Rear
France - 25 February 1918
My dear General:
div1.p:
Your note of January 14 reached me on February 22, having had the
misfortune of a slow trip, as has been the luck of most of your letters.
Today I had a letter from Allentown which was mailed on February 5.

I have already written you about General Pershing's sudden determina-
tion to send me to the Headquarters, Line of Communications, as Chief
Surgeon. About the time this order was issued there was a grand meeting
of the General Staff at Headquarters, which determined that the Headquarters
was too much overburdened with routine business to function properly and so
was getting smothered in papers. They therefore made a radical recommenda-
tion, which has been approved and carried out by General Pershing, to turn
over his administrative staffs to General Kernan, Commanding the Line of
Communications, and consolidate them with the corresponding divisions of
General Kernan's staff. To correspond with these new functions, the
name of the service is changed from Line of Communications to Service
of the Rear. As this involves the moving of most of the officers and
clerical force from Chaumont to Tours, Generals Bradley and Ireland came
to Paris and came down with me to Tours by automobile, on Sunday, the
17th. Therefore I reported to General Kernan as Chief Surgeon, L.O.C.,
and General Bradley within half an hour afterwards reported to him as
Chief Surgeon, A.E.F.; and I lost my new position immediately. I am now
here as his principal assistant, the plan being that he will be absent
a good deal, either with General Pershing or inspecting, and that I will
act as Chief Surgeon, A.E.F., during his absence, being thus a sort of
Deputy Chief Surgeon. A certain number of Bradley's assistants will be
left on duty with the four sections of the General Staff at Headquarters,
but most of them will come down here and this office will be organised
into divisions, much like the former organization of your office.

I of course regret leaving my fine little Ambulance Service with the
French Army, which was just beginning to run smoothly and to be a joy:
I have left it, however, in very safe and competent hands, with Percy
Jones as Chief. I do not know of any man who handles men better and has
better qualifications for this special service than Jones, and I hope that
when Persons gets his Colonelcy in the regular service you will see that
Jones gets the Colonelcy in the Ambulance Service which he will vacate.
I think he will get along all right with Andrew, who really was beginning
to pull in harness fairly well at the time I left. Andrew has charge of
the most important division of the office, the motor transportation and
motor supplies, and has been a good deal discouraged at the difficulties
which the Quartermaster Department has made for him. They started out
by insisting that it was their business to furnish spare parts, and so
they refused to let our service make arrangements for so doing. Their
next step was to steal all the spare parts which had been sent to us and
distribute them through their own depot. Their third step has been to
refuse to purchase in Paris a stock of spare parts to run on until their
own supplies came in. They have only been willing to make piecemeal emer-
gency purchases, with many delays and much fussing. I understand, however,
2 - General Gorgas - 25 Feb 1918
-----
now that the 60 tons of spare parts for the Ambulance Service which ar-
rived some weeks ago at Bordeaux are now in Paris, so the service will
be on easy street for a while. The arrival of the 10 sections under
Devereux, and the 17 under Metcalf has relieved the situation entirely
as regards personnel. Devereux's sections, after assembling their cars
at St. Nazaire, have come up and are now partly at the Base Camp and
partly at the front. The others will follow soon.

We have not heard any details about the plan to send the sections
remaining in the United States to Italy. It is my understanding that
General Pershing does not view it with favor, but I got this at third-hand.
As we have no troops in Italy it would involve the fitting out of a regular
military expedition with a complete line of Quartermaster supplies, trans-
portation, spare parts, etc., etc. This would have to be done, I suppose,
by the Chief Quartermaster, AEF, and as they have been very hard up for
supplies and transportation themselves they naturally do not view with any
enthusiasm the fitting out of an Italian expedition.

Birmingham writes me the good news that there is every probability
of our getting a half dozen medical Brigadiers for the service in France.
I think that there are a number of quite suitable appointments for them
here, as, for example, the surgeons of the different sections, which under
the decentralization scheme will be given the authority of Department
Chief Surgeons in the United States; and also the positions of supervision
and control over the hospital centers, where groups of base hospitals will
be collected which will receive a number of thousand patients. To command
these centers will certainly be as important, and have as large administra-
tive responsibilities as the commander of a brigade at the front.

Everyone is happy that the winter is nearing its end. While we have
not had the unexampled severity of the winter in the United States, it
has been cold, dark and gloomy, and all will be glad to see the sun.

Please reproach Furbush for having never written to me. I was
greatly pleased to hear of Goodwin's fine promotion.
With cordial messages to all my friends in the office, I am,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J R Kean Major General W. C. Gorgas, USA
Chief Surgeon
War Dept., Washington
